name: Ammonite
description: Ammonites are extinct marine mollusks with beautiful spiral shells. They were dominant predators in ancient oceans and evolved into many different shapes and sizes over millions of years. Their shells are often used as index fossils to date rock layers.

name: Trilobite
description: Trilobites were among the most successful animals in Earth's history. These three-lobed marine arthropods had segmented bodies and complex eyes. They dominated the oceans for nearly 300 million years before going extinct in the Permian-Triassic extinction event.

name: Graptolite
description: Graptolites were small colonial marine animals that lived in the plankton. Their fossils are commonly found in sedimentary rocks and are excellent for dating rocks from the Ordovician, Silurian, and Devonian periods. The name means 'written in rock' due to their writing-like appearance.

name: Brachiopod
description: Brachiopods are marine animals with two shells (valves) that resemble clams, but they are completely unrelated. They attached to the seafloor using a muscular stalk called a pedicle. Brachiopods were particularly abundant during the Paleozoic Era and are still alive today.

name: Crinoid
description: Crinoids are marine echinoderms with flower-like appearances, often called 'sea lilies' even though they are animals, not plants. They have a cup-shaped body with arms used for filter feeding. In the Paleozoic, they formed extensive marine ecosystems and their skeletal remains contribute to limestone formations.

name: Coral
description: Corals are colonial animals that build rock-like structures through calcium carbonate secretion. Fossil corals reveal past ocean conditions and are particularly useful for understanding ancient reef ecosystems. Modern corals face severe threats from ocean acidification and warming.

name: Foraminifera
description: Foraminifera are single-celled protozoans with shells made of calcium carbonate or sand grains. Though tiny (usually less than 2mm), they are incredibly abundant in marine sediments. Their fossils are extensively used in oil exploration and studying paleoclimate.

name: Belemnite
description: Belemnites were squid-like marine cephalopods that had an internal shell. They hunted small fish and crustaceans in Mesozoic seas. The solid internal shell (rostrum) is the part most commonly preserved as fossils, often resembling stone bullets.
